title: 111_s3810
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" and includes a restriction on participation in offshore oil and gas leasing. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" mandates that leases for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf include a certification requirement to ensure compliance with Iran sanctions. Failure to certify annually may result in lease cancellation. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" requires leaseholders on the Outer Continental Shelf to annually certify to the Secretary that they are not engaging in activities subject to sanctions under the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. The Secretary is authorized to cancel the lease if the certification is false or not provided. If the person fails to make the required certification, the Secretary, in consultation with other relevant departments, may determine that the certification is false. The Secretary may cancel a lease on the Outer Continental Shelf if the lessee fails to provide a required certification or provides a false certification. The Secretary of the Interior must include a disclosure requirement in leases authorizing drilling for oil and gas. The Secretary may cancel a lease on the Outer Continental Shelf if the lessee fails to provide a required certification or provides a false certification. The Secretary of the Interior must include a disclosure requirement in leases authorizing drilling for oil and gas on the Outer Continental Shelf. The Secretary must be informed of any involvement in energy-related ventures outside Iran with individuals whose assets are blocked under Executive Order 13224. Order 13224 (66 Fed. Reg. 49079) blocks property and prohibits transactions with persons involved in terrorism, Executive Order 13382 (70 Fed. Reg. 38567) blocks property of weapons of mass destruction proliferators, and entities listed on appendix A are also included. Interests in property are blocked under Executive Order 13382 and entities listed on appendix A to part 560 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. The Secretary is authorized to cancel the lease if disclosure requirements are not met. The Secretary can cancel the lease if disclosure requirements are not met for entities listed on appendix A to part 560 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. The Secretary, in consultation with other departments, can cancel a lease if a person fails to make a required disclosure or provides false information. The Secretary of the Interior may waive this requirement on a case-by-case basis if it is in the national interest. The Secretary of the Interior can cancel a lease if disclosure requirements are not met or false information is provided. The Secretary may waive this requirement on a case-by-case basis if it is in the national interest, with reporting requirements for waivers granted. The Secretary of the Interior can cancel a lease if disclosure requirements are not met or false information is provided, with reporting requirements for waivers granted in the national interest. The Secretary must promptly report any lease cancellations to appropriate congressional committees. The Secretary of the Interior must report lease cancellations to congressional committees, including reasons for the cancellation. "Appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "person" is defined in the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. The appropriate congressional committees include the Committee on Natural Resources, Committee on Foreign Affairs, Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, and Committee on Foreign Relations. SEC. 3. SUNSET. The Act will end 30 days after the President certifies to Congress that Iran has permanently stopped supporting international terrorism and no longer meets the criteria for being designated as a state sponsor of terrorism. This includes the pursuit, acquisition, and development of nuclear, biological, and chemical weapons and missiles, as well as posing no significant threat to United States national security, interests, or allies.
